topic.title: Loading and Unloading of Binary Packages

keywords.keyword: Loading and Unloading of Binary Packages

para.text: Loading and Unloading of Binary Packages

para.style: text-align:left; text-indent:0px; margin-top:9px; margin-right:0px; margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:0px; line-height:1.46; background-color:transparent; white-space:normal; page-break-inside:auto; page-break-after:auto; border:none; tabstops:none;

text.style: font-family:Verdana; font-size:10pt; font-weight:normal; font-style:normal; text-decoration:none; text-transform:none; vertical-align:baseline; color:#000000; background-color:transparent; letter-spacing:normal; letter-scaling:100%;

para.text: A Binary Package can be loaded into an

, on demand, when a request for one of its constituent classes is encountered. Normally, for an applet, this occurs within the jurisdiction of the Dolphin browser plug-in but, as will be seen later, it is also possible to explicitly load Binary Packages into any image if you wish.

para.style: text-align:left; text-indent:0px; margin-top:14px; margin-right:0px; margin-bottom:14px; margin-left:0px; line-height:1.46; background-color:transparent; white-space:normal; page-break-inside:auto; page-break-after:auto; border:none; tabstops:none;

text.style: font-family:Verdana; font-size:10pt; font-weight:normal; font-style:normal; text-decoration:none; text-transform:none; vertical-align:baseline; color:#000000; background-color:transparent; letter-spacing:normal; letter-scaling:100%;

para.text: Once a package has been successfully imported into an image then all of its classes are available for the duration of that session. When an image starts, however, the

text.style: font-family:Verdana; font-size:10pt; font-weight:normal; font-style:normal; text-decoration:none; text-transform:none; vertical-align:baseline; color:#000000; background-color:transparent; letter-spacing:normal; letter-scaling:100%;

para.text: class ensures that any imported packages currently held as part of the image are cleared down. In this way, binary packages are treated differently from source packages; they cannot be loaded into an image and remain there across sessions.
